subtasks: Sitting on the tractor seat
Operating the steering wheel to turn the tractor
Engaging the clutch and shifting gears
Manipulating the throttle to control speed
Using the brake pedal to stop the tractor

tasks.task: Attaching a plow to the tractor
subtasks: Guiding the plow into place on the tractor
Ensuring the plow is securely attached
Adjusting the plow settings (if necessary)
Starting the tractor engine
Operating the plow to turn over the soil
Navigating through the field, moving the tractor forward
Making turns at the end of the field
Stopping the tractor when a specific distance is plowed
Driving the tractor with attached wagon to the hay field
Maneuvering the tractor and wagon to position under the hay
Raising the wagon's front end to receive the hay
Lowering the wagon's forked prongs to load the hay
Elevating the fork to pick up the hay bales
Lowering the fork onto the wagon, secure the bales

tasks.task: Unloading hay from wagon onto barn
subtasks: Driving the wagon with hay to the barn
Aligning the wagon with the hay entry point
Lowering the hay fork to extract hay bales
Loading the hay into the barn by hand or using another device
Stacking the hay bales in the barn
Walking to the area where the fence is broken
Gathering needed tools (e.g., tools for repairing fences)
Removing the damaged parts of the fence
Installing new fence panels or repairing existing ones
Tightening posts and ensuring stability
Approach the dairy cow and prepare to milk
Clean the cow's udder using water and a cloth
Attach the milking device (e.g., suction cups) to the teats
Begin milking the cow, ensuring proper technique
Switch milking devices between front and rear quarters
Collect milk into a container
Gathering feed for the animals (e.g., grain, hay)
Transporting the feed to the barn or animal housing
Distributing feed to the animals through appropriate methods (e.g., fodder boxes, feeding troughs)
Walking through the fields to inspect crop health
Observing for any signs of pests, diseases, or drought stress
Noting areas that need irrigation or fertilization
Collecting samples if necessary for crop analysis
Preparing the soil by loosening it with a tiller or plow
Mixing in fertilizers or pesticides if required
Broadcasting or sowing seeds at the appropriate depth and spacing
Covering the seeds with soil using a rake or culti-vator
Riding in the tractor with the haystack, then detaching
Positioning the hay loader onto the haystack
Raising the forks to scoop up hay bales
Lowering the hay bales onto the moving wagon
Securing the bales on the wagon for transport
Mixing the chemicals in the sprayer tank
Attaching the appropriate nozzle or applicator to the sprayer
Calibrating the sprayer for the correct application rate
Drifting through the fields to apply the chemical uniformly
Monitoring wind conditions to avoid drift
Setting the combine for the appropriate crop (e.g., wheat, corn)
Attaching header and appropriate cutting height
Operating the combine to cut, thresh, and clean the grain
Loading the grain into the wagon or truck
Cleaning the combine between different types of crops
Identifying the problem with the tractor
Gathering the necessary tools and replacement parts
Disassembling the faulty component
Replacing or fixing the part (e.g., broken belt, clogged filter)
Reassembling the tractor and testing it
Ensuring adequate shelter for the animals (e.g., barn, shed)
Providing proper insulation or heating in the shelter
Storing extra feed to prevent waste
Checking water sources regularly to ensure they are not frozen
Locating the water source (e.g., pond, well)
Connecting the sprinkler system or irrigation hoses
Starting the water pump or operating the irrigation system
Monitoring the water distribution to ensure even coverage
Cutting hay with a sickle or scythe
Tying the hay into bundles
Stacking the hay in the field to dry
